contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox UK place | official_name= Kimbolton | country= England | region= East of England | os_grid_reference= TL102681 | latitude= 52.3 | longitude= -0.38 | post_town= | postcode_area= | postcode_district= | dial_code= |civil_parish= [[Kimbolton and Stonely]] |shire_district= [[Huntingdonshire]] | shire_county= [[Cambridgeshire]] |static_image_name = Kimbolton - geograph.org.uk - 900226.jpg |static_image_caption = <small>Kimbolton High Street</small> }} '''Kimbolton''' is a large [[village]] in the [[Huntingdonshire]] district of [[Cambridgeshire]], [[England]]. It is approximately {{convert|7|mi|0}} east of [[Higham Ferrers]], {{convert|7|mi|0}} west of [[St Neots]] and {{convert|24|mi|0}} west of [[Cambridge]], {{convert|14|mi|0}} north of Bedford and {{convert|31|mi|0}} south of [[Peterborough]]. ==Castle== The centre of the village is [[Kimbolton Castle]] which now forms the main building of [[Kimbolton School]] (an independent day and [[boarding school]]), but its predecessor on the same site was once home and prison to [[Katherine of Aragon]] after her divorce from [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]. Katherine died at Kimbolton Castle in 1536 and was transported from there to [[Peterborough Cathedral]] to be buried.<ref>[http://www.britainexpress.com/counties/cambridgeshire/az/kimbolton.htm Britain Express]</ref> ==History== Kimbolton, and the lands of its [[Soke (legal)|soke]], comprised the only estate of [[Harold Godwinson|King Harold]] in Huntingdonshire. It is believed that Harold had a hunting lodge nearby. Kimbolton and its church, [[St Andrew]]'s, appear in the [[Domesday book]], compiled in 1086. The main road through Kimbolton bends through four tight [[angle|right angle]]s in quick succession. Originally, the road travelled directly through the outskirts of the village, nearer to the [[River Kym]] to the north. ==Statute Fair== In 1200, a prominent local landowner, [[Geoffrey Fitz Peter, 1st Earl of Essex|Geoffrey Fitz Peter]], [[Earl of Essex]] and [[Chief Justice]] to [[John of England|King John]], who constructed the first castle on the present site, received a [[Royal charter]] to hold a market and fair in Kimbolton. There is still a fair every September, known as the "Statute Fair" - referred to affectionately by locals as the "Statty". Continuation of this fair (despite the chaos which formerly ensued when this meant partial closure of a trunk road) and a plaque marking the site of the market cross are claimed by some as evidence that Kimbolton is a town and still has a right to hold a weekly market. The main road was diverted to its present course to take it through the market place and increase toll revenue. 800 years later, as a result of numerous vehicles striking walls and houses near the sharp bends, car transporters are not allowed in the village. [[File:Kimbolton fire station - geograph.org.uk - 629799.jpg|thumb|Kimbolton fire station]] ==Facilities== Kimbolton is known locally for its facilities, including High Street shopping, three public houses, a garage, fire station and the Mandeville Hall. ==Kimbolton Airfield== In [[World War II]], the [[USAF]] [[379th Bombardment Group]] was stationed at the nearby [[Kimbolton Airfield]] from May 1943 to June 1945. ==Kimbolton Fireworks== [[Kimbolton Fireworks]], a well-known manufacturer of fireworks and organiser of public fireworks displays, is based in Kimbolton.<ref>[http://www.kimboltonfireworks.co.uk/ Kimbolton Fireworks]</ref> It grew from the extracurricular activities of Kimbolton School chaplain and chemistry master, Rev Ron Lancaster, sometimes dubbed the "master blaster pastor." ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.countryfayre.info/ The annual Country Fayre at Kimbolton (at the castle)] * [http://www.kimbolton-online.co.uk/ Kimbolton Web site] * [http://www.kimbolton.cambs.sch.uk/ Kimbolton School (the castle)] * [http://www.standrew-kimbolton.org.uk/ The parish church] [[Category:Villages in Cambridgeshire]] [[Category:Huntingdonshire]]
